channel.title: Compass Rose Careers
channel.description: New Directions for People in Transition

wp:category.wp:category_description: Services for people changing careers or exploring new career options.
How to succeed in job interviews

How to develop a resume that goes to the top of the pile.

item.title: Resumes That Work
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
How To Write a Winning Resume

The purpose of a resume is to show that you're the best person for the job.  It should get you a job interview. It is not a complete history of every place you've worked and everything you did there. It does not contain long, involved descriptions of your jobs.
  •  A great resume is short and specific.  Every item on it is designed to show how you fit the bill for a specific job. Limit it to one or two pages.
  • A great resume is skill and competency-based, which means it shows the employer what you can do and how your previous experience relates to the new position.  A great resume mentions the results of your efforts. If you indicate, and better yet, quantify the results of your efforts, your resume will rise to the top of the pile.
  • A great resume is targeted to a specific job. If you have lots of experience, and are interested in more than one type of job, you may need more than one document
The Skill or Competency-Based Résumé
  • Based on research into competencies required for the new job
  • Details skills, abilities and accomplishments first, at the top of the page
  • Demonstrates how you acquired the core competencies
  • Omits all extraneous information
What You Need to Know to Write a Great Résumé
  • A list of all your jobs, including your titles and dates of employment
  • A list of your most transferable skills that are relevant to the new position
  • Results of your efforts on your most recent and most relevant jobs
  • The competencies needed in the jobs for which you are applying
  • List of your schools, degrees and certificates, especially if recent

Sample Resumes

Functional Resume   sample-res-1

Chronological Resume:   sample-res-2

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What You Need to Know to Write a Great Resume that Gets Results. Format, style, and length are all important, but does your resume show what you can do?
How to Write a Great Resume

item.title: Services
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
A job search plan details your

  • goals
  • skills
  • talents
  • education and training
  • companies you've researched
  • talking points for interviews
In today’s business climate, you need to be open to new ways of looking for work, even if getting jobs has been easy for you up until now. You need to be focused. You need to do your homework. You must have a great resume tailored to your goal.  You need to use all methods of job hunting--agencies, newspaper ads, the Internet, social media, professional organizations, networking, and anything else you can think of to get yourself in front of the decision-makers who can hire you.

Career Coaching Services

Individual consulting on any aspect of the job search:
  • choosing new options
  • career transition
  • self employment
  • developing a strategy
  • identifying your skills
  • researching employers
  • how to interview effectively
  • negotiating salary and benefits
During the first session, we will develop a plan based on your goals. No minimum number of hours are required. For New Mexico residents, office hours in Albuquerque for coaching are available. Call 505-235-9753 to make an appointment. Hourly rate is $45. Consulting by phone and email can be arranged on any job search topic. Hourly rate for phone or email contact is $45. Call or email to make an appointment. Coaching and Editing for fiction and nonfiction writers.  Check out my writing site at Carol Holland March if you are interested in writing classes or consultation on your writing.  

Resume Development Services

Free email critique of your current document. Send it to info@compassrosecareers.com   Put "Critique" in the Header line.  You will receive a complimentary critique of the strengths and weaknesses of your document within 48 hours. If you want help writing or editing your resume, you can come in for a personal consultation; OR, we can talk on the phone about what you would like; OR, you can send an  email about your goals, skills, work history and education. The cost to develop a one-page resume with a covero letter is $75. Fees for a two-page resume start at $100. You will have a clearly quoted price before the work begins. Turnaround is 2-3 days.  Rush orders can be accommodated for an additional $25 fee. Cover Letters and Follow-up Letters are a MUST if you want to be successful. Letters can be written for specific jobs or you can order a basic letter about your skills and experience that you can tailor to different jobs on your own.   To ask a question, make a comment, request services or send a resume for evaluation, you can use the form below.

item.title: Career Interest Tests
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: Do you need a test to tell you what you like? Career interest tests predict what jobs, career areas and types of organizations will fit you best.  They do this by analyzing your responses to questions describing activities, school subjects, careers, and types of people. Interest tests help you understand how your likes and dislikes translate into career choices. They work because most of us do best at things we enjoy . . .  obvious but also true! But what if you’re not sure what you like?  Maybe you like a lot of things.  Maybe you haven’t worked in a lot of different jobs, so you don’t have a way to compare. The occupations and career areas suggested by an interest test are meant to suggest ideas for your own research, not tell you what to do.  Use the results as one piece of the puzzle that you’re putting together.  You may get ideas from your test results that you’ve never thought about. Remember,  most people who are successful like what they. They go with their strengths.  Your strengths and your interests are two sides of the same coin.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "career interest test", career choice", occupations, testing
Do you need a test to tell you what you like? An interest test can help you focus, give you new ideas to explore, and validate your impressions about your strengths.

item.title: Where Can I Take an Interest Test?
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: When choosing a career interest test, pick one that has a solid history.  The Strong Interest Inventory is the most widely used instrument.  Your scores are compared to all the scores of thousands of different employees in hundreds of occupations who have taken the same test.  The scoring is so complex a computer must do it, but the test is easy to take in about 20-30 minutes. The Strong is used by career counselors, coaches, and college counseling centers.  You might be able to take it free at your local college.  If you take a paper and pencil version, it must be sent to a testing center and scored by a computer, so expect your results in about a week.  The Strong uses the Holland system of classifying interests.  This gives you a 3-letter score of how you scored on Realistic, Investigative, Artistic, Social, Enterprising, and Conventional occupations. The Self Directed Search is also based on the Holland system.  You get a report with your 3-letter Holland Code and a list of occupations to research.  It takes about 20 minutes online and the fee is $4.95.  www.self-directed-search.com The Career Key was developed by Dr. Lawrence Jones as a public service and has been validated on large number of people. The test costs $9.95 to take. If you know your Holland Code, you can use the site to research careers and occupational descriptions.  www.careerkey.org The O’Net Interest Profiler is the Department of Labor’s instrument. It is free and the site contains useful information on job descriptions and skills.  You can look up any job title and find extensive descriptions of the job duties and required skills. You can even check out the average salaries for any job, nationally and by state. To take the ONet Interest Profiler go to www.careerinfonet.org/explore/view.aspx. Look for Interest Profiler.  You have to download the software, but it’s quick and easy.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: An interest test can give you ideas about your personal preferences relate to jobs, careers, and organizations. The Strong Inventory gives you a 3-letter Holland Score.
Where Can I Take an Interest Test

item.title: What Kinds of Work Do You Like? The Holland Codes
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Holland’s theory is that there are six kinds of people and six kinds of work environments. If you know you’re 3-letter Holland code, you can relate your characteristics to many kinds of jobs. Realistic people like to work with machines, tools, and numbers. They prefer less involvement with people. They have mechanical aptitude and like physical challenges. They like to work outdoors and on activities where they accomplish tasks by DOING, like building and repairing.

I or Investigative people like to work with data, numbers, tools, and machines more than people. They like work environments that involve observing, learning, evaluating, and thinking through problems. They do not enjoy structured settings and are often creative in scientific areas. They like to achieve by THINKING.

A for Artistic people like work environments that are unstructured and allow for personal expression and creative work. They prefer working with words, images, and numbers, less with people. They like to work alone. The achieve by CREATING.

S for Social people who like to help others. They like to work with people, in groups and in organizations where they can be concerned about the well being of others. They like to use their communication skills at work. They are less interested in data, tools, and machines. They achieve by HELPING.

E is for enterprising people who like environments where they can lead, persuade, and manage people, where competition is important and taking risks leads to success. They enjoy work environments with high involvement with people and low involvement with machines. They enjoy persuading others and are impatient with precise work. They achieve by PERSUADING.

 C is for Conventional people who like work environments where they can follow routines, meet standards, and be responsible, using clerical and math abilities and organizing. They like low involvement with people; low-moderate with tools and machines and moderate involvement with words and numbers. They do not seek leadership and they value contributing to an organization within an established chain of command. They achieve by FOLLOWING RULES.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What Kinds of work do you like? The Holland Codes
There are six kinds of people and six kinds of work environments. If you know you’re 3-letter Holland code, you can predict what jobs you will like.

item.title: What's Your Type?
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Personality tests help you understand yourself so you can make better career decisions. They will:
  • understand yourself and others
  • identify what careers people who are like you prefer and are successful doing
  • understand how personality traits suggest potential careers
The best personality tests have been around for a long time.  They have been validated on many people and found to predict success in both school and work situations. The Meyers Briggs Type Indicator gives you a four-letter “type” score based on four preferences:  Extraversion/Introversion; Sensing/Intuition; Thinking/Feeling; Judging/Perceiving.  Type has been correlated with college majors, jobs, career areas, goal-setting, making decisions, job satisfaction and interpersonal relationships. I have used this instrument extensively and have found it as helpful as the Strong in working with people in transition. Your type can be taken online in about 30 minutes.  Here are two sites that offer it free of charge http://www. humanmetrics.com/  http://www.keirsey.com

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Personality tests help you relate your personal characteristics to the requirements of many different jobs.

item.title: Cover Letters Are a Must
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
When you send a resume to an employer, by email, fax, or snail mail, always send a covering letter with it. The letter introduces you to the recipient, says what you are looking for, and requests an appointment. It should be written in professional but friendly languagand encourage the reader to look at your resume.

 Cover letters should be brief, specifically targeted to the organization, and addressed to an individual. If you don’t know the name of the person you need to write to, find out. No one is impressed with a form letter. While a resume is written for a particular type of position and may apply to jobs in many different organizations, the letter is directed to a specific job. Cover these points in each letter: 1. State who you are and why you are writing. If you’ve been referred by someone else, mention the name, company, and title in the first paragraph. Mention the position for which you are applying. 2.  State briefly, in one or two paragraphs, why you are qualified for the position.     Mention two or three accomplishments that relate to the position you are  targeting. Do not repeat what is in your resume. 3. Make a positive statement about the company/department. If you know nothing about the company, go online and find out what has been written about it recently in the business press. Check out the company’s website. 4. Request an interview. Be assertive. State when you will place a follow-up call about an appointment. Thank the recipient for reading your resume and letter.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A brief targeted cover letter should be send along with your resume, whether you email, fax or snail mail it. Be sure to personalize each letter.

item.title: A Quick Way to Clarify Your Career Goal
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Here is a quick method to get you thinking about what you really want to do.  Try using these four simple steps to clarify your goal.   1.   Choose one or two of your favorite skills/talents/abilities and complete the following sentence: My goal is to use my ________________________ Example:  My goal is to use my communication skills . . .   2.   Review your list of action words to find the action you can see yourself doing in relation to your general skill area.

          Some action words include:   assist, promote, guide, promote, motivate, discover, organize, sell,

            stimulate, encourage, persuade, help, interpret, activate, manage, teach, organiz

My goal is to use my _____________skills to____________ people to . .

Example: My goal is to use my communication skills to support people to . . .   3. Decide if you want to qualify what type of people you want to be working with. For example, women, minorities, rich, poor, etc. My goal is to use my ____________skills to ____________women to . . . Example:  My goal is to use my communication skills to help women to . . .   4.  What  is the final product you'd like to see in that other person?  What is the result of your work with him/her. In the example, I need to determine what it is I want to help women to BE, DO or HAVE THE COMPLETED EXAMPLE:  My goal is to use my communication skills to help women find better jobs. 

What is your goal?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A Quick Way to Clarify Your Career Goal
Use these four simple steps to guide you in deciding what skills you want to use and what you want to do next.

item.title: Some Questions To Ask Yourself if You're in Transition
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: If you are in transition because you were laid off, your company downsized, you don't like what you've done in the past, or you see future opportunities shrinking in your field, it pays to take some time and think about what you want in your next position.   These are some questions to get you started. To make my transition, I might need to change….   If things to well in the next five years, I will be doing:    If things do not go well in the next five years, I will be doing:   Who Am I? ________________________________________ ________________________________________ _______________________________________     What are my strongest skills?   What do I want most in my next position?    What kinds of problems do I want to solve?    Who is in my network?    What is my next step?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: When you find yourself in career transition, voluntary or not, it pays to take the time to analyze who you are and what you want in your next position.
Some Questions to Ask When You're in Career Transition

item.title: Questions You Can Ask an Employer In a Job Interview
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Many people ask me what are good questions to ask in a job interview.  Here are a few examples:

  • What do you see as this position's responsibilities on a regular basis?
  • What are the most important responsibilities of this position?
  • What was the reason for this position's vacancy? (
  • How long does the average employee remain with your company?
  • What are this company’s current challenges?
  • What do you view as this company’s greatest goals and missions?
  • Has this company experienced a downsizing at any time in its history, and if so, when?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Questions to ask an employer in an interview
It's important to have questions for the employer when you go for an interview. Research and company and develop questions that show you're thinking about the company

item.title: Five Ways To Make Your Resume Stand Out From the Crowd!
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
You can do a few simple things to assure your resume does not end up in the “No” pile.
  1.  If you use an objective, list the job for which you are applying.  No long flowery statements about what you want or hope to achieve. A tight focus is best. If you’re tight for space, the objective can be eliminated on the resume and put into the cover letter.
  2. Neat, clean, and easy to read. No fancy fonts. No graphics or pictures (unless you’re a graphic artist). Use one font and change the size for headers. Leave plenty of white space or it will be unreadable. The most important information should be in the top one third of the first page.
  3.  Focus on accomplishments, not job duties. What made you different (and better!) than everyone else who did the same job? What did you contribute? What were the results of your work?
  4. Omit extraneous information not related to the job in question. No hobbies, memberships, interests, or jobs that do not support your job goal.
  5.  Use a chronological format or a combination functional/chronological format. A straight functional resume is often not accepted by employers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: You can do a few simple things to assure your resume does not end up in the “No” pile.
Five Ways To Make Your Resume Stand Out From the Crowd!

item.title: What NOT to Include On Your Resume
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Some people think the more information they include on a resume, the better. This is NOT true. Only include what will support your job goal and convince the person reading it to contact you for an interview. Some things you DO NOT include are:
  • Salary information - can be used to screen you out
  • Photograph – can be used to discriminate against you
  • Date of birth, marital status, children – all items that can be used to discriminate. It is illegal for an employer to ask you about these items, so why volunteer them?
  • Reasons for leaving a job – this is for a formal application, not a resume
  • Start date – listing this can make you look desperate. Don’t bring it up unless you are asked in an interview
  • References – are not included on the resume, but on a separate sheet that you   provide the employer only when asked to do so
Use the resume to highlight your measurable achievements, work history, and relevant education to make the best impression.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What NOT to Include On Your Resume

Some people think the more information they include on a resume, the better. This is NOT true. Only include what will support your job goal and convince the person reading it to contact you for an interview.

item.title: Does Your Resume Pass the Language Test?
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Clear, concise language gives the impression that you are a serious, professional  job applicant. There are some simple things you can do to make sure your document presents you in the best possible light.
  •  Start every sentence in your Summary and Professional Experience sections with an action verb. Always use the past tense. For example: Taught; supervised; delivered; organized; trained; managed. Avoid passive constructions like “a report was developed.” Say “researched and wrote a report.”
  • Be concise. Shorter is better. Don’t use flowery phrases, clichés, or excessive adjectives. Everyone is busy and by being brief, you are showing that you respect the employer’s time.
  •  Don’t use jargon or buzzwords. Say what you did, how well you did it, and what the results were of your effort in simple, clear words.
  • Be specific. Avoid general phrases that sound like a generic job description. Don’t say “taught classes”; instead say, “taught MS Word basic skills to ten newly hired administrative employees per month.”
  • Don’t depend on spell check. Have someone read your document for typos, misspellings, and grammatical errors.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Clear, concise language gives the impression that you are a serious, professional job applicant.
Does Your Resume Pass the Language Test?

item.title: What Format Is Best for You?
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
How you organize your resume matters. Employers look for skills, accomplishments, experience, and education that directly relates to their needs. The most important information about you, what will sell you most strongly, should be in the top half of the first page of your resume.
Use a Chronological Format if your most recent work experience relates directly to your job goal. List your jobs in date order starting with the most recent. If your career has progressed in an orderly way, this is the most effective way to present your skills.
Use a Functional Format if your skills and experience are in several different fields, if you have breaks of time in your work record, or if you are returning to the job market. Use a Summary to present your strongest skills as the first item, and list your jobs at the bottom. Note: some employers do not like the Functional Format because they want to know where you acquired your skills.
Use the Combination Format (first page a summary of functional skills; second page a chronological listing of work experience) if you have more than 15 years of diverse experience, if you have worked in many different industries or if you are changing careers. When done well, this format can be very effective.
No matter what format you choose, your resume must look clear and attractive, with plenty of “white space” and no unusual fonts or graphics.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How you organize your resume matters. Chronological, functional and combination are the most common types of organization.
What Format Is Best for You?

item.title: What Makes a Great Resume?
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: To make sure your resume goes to the top of the pile, be sure you have included a clear description of your accomplishments on each recent job. Accomplishments are NOT job descriptions. They are NOT a list of job duties. They are NOT generic. So what are they? Accomplishments are specific statements of what you did, how well you did it, and the results of your efforts. Think about what you did differently than every other person in your organization that had a similar job.  Examples of results-driven accomplishment statements Researched and wrote a 40-page training manual that was used to train 10 new sales representatives per month on company policies and sales techniques. Developed a new filing system that significantly reduced filing time for administrative staff, resulting in higher productivity and higher customer satisfaction as measured by annual surveys. As an exercise, look at your current resume. Choose one statement about what you did from your most recent job. Is it specific? Does it include results? Are the results measured in some way? Could the employer reading it tell if you will bring value to her company? It is worth the time to rewrite your job duties as accomplishment statements. Be sure to start each sentence with an action verb in the past tense!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Accomplishments are specific statements of what you did, how well you did it, and the results of your efforts.

item.title: How to Tailor Your Resume to a Company
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: You can’t write a great resume without knowing what you’re going to do with it. A generic document will not take you far in this job market. But how do you know what a company looks for?  Good question. And the only way you can answer it is to research the company.  The Internet The good news is that you can learn a lot just by searching the web. Check out the company’s website. Look for their mission statement, what their public relations department has put out about them. Check out their job descriptions.  Industry Publications Another resource is industry publications. If you keep up to date on what’s going on, you’ll have a better chance of a meaningful connection during an interview.  Business Press For large companies, check both the local and national presses. Search for articles about what the company is doing, what new personnel have been hired, community involvement, new acquisitions. Networking Use your networking contacts to find someone who works in the company. Insider information is often the best source for how to present yourself. Culture If you learn about the values and culture of a company, it’s much easier to tailor the language on your resume to match. Is it a highly formal organization? A more casual or collaborative environment? Do they value teamwork? Achievement? Academic qualifications? The more you learn about your target organizations, and incorporate what you learn into your resume, the more likely your resume will go into the “YES” pile.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How to Tailor Your Resume to a Company
You can’t write a great resume without knowing what you’re going to do with it. Research is the key to tailoring your resume to a specific company.

item.title: What Do Employers Want?
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: If you’re called for an interview, chances are you’re qualified for the job. You have the education, experience, and skills they want, based on your resume. But during the interview, how do employers discriminate among several qualified candidates? Research shows that employers are usually looking for certain personality traits such as confidence, positive communication, high energy, and professionalism. When you walk into an interview, be prepared. Do your homework. Learn as much as you can about the company, its current challenges, and its culture. Do enough research that you can be dressed appropriately for their culture. Employers are looking for people who will fit in without effort. Be upbeat. Start the interview with a firm handshake. Smile. Tell the interviewer that you’re glad to be there and why. If you don’t, others will. During the interview, mention how you have achieved results in previous positions. Mention accomplishments that show you are a self-starter with initiative. If you saved money or time, developed new projects, or came up solutions to problems, you will make a positive impression! And don’t forget to use the SAR formula when talking about what you’ve done. Mention the situation What action you took What results you achieved.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: If you’re called for an interview, chances are you’re qualified for the job. You have the education, experience, and skills they want, based on your resume. But how do employers discriminate among several qualified candidates?

item.title: Follow Up to Stand Out
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
After every contact with an employer--job interview, informational interview, phone call--follow up with a personal letter, email or call.
Which method works best depends upon the employer and the level of interaction.
If you went through a formal job interview, a letter is the most conservative way to follow up. It doesn't have to be long. Just a brief statement of how much you enjoyed meeting the employer and that you are interested in the job is sufficient. However, if you forgot to mention something important in the interview, this is a great opportunity to bring it up. Or maybe you've had an idea on how the employer might solve a problem or challenge that came up during the interview. This is your chance to shine!
If your interactions with the employer have been via email, then an email message might be fine. Another reason to be sure to get the employer's business card during the interview.
A followup should be done within a few days of the interview. Remember, it will make you stand out, so a little extra effort is worth the time you put in.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: After every contact with an employer--job interview, informational interview, phone call--follow up with a personal letter, email or call.

item.title: Get a Better Job in 2013
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
The holidays are over. It's time to get serious about finding that new job. So what's the first step?
  • Setting a goal is a good place to start.  What are you looking for?  What skills do you want to use in your next job?  What kind of environment would you prefer? Write down all the aspects of work that you want in your next position.
  • Making a plan is the next step. Use a computer, a calendar, or a notebook.  Write down your goals, your ideas on how to proceed, companies your interested in, people you can contact.
  • Add dates to your plan. A goal without a date attached is a wish.  Get serious with yourself about how much time you have to devote to your job search.  Make your goals realistic. Don't forget to include research time. Job seekers who take the time to prepare are more successful than those who "wing" it.
  • Ask for help. Looking for a job is lonely.  Find a buddy, a support group,or a professional consultant to help you stay on track.
  • Stay positive. Employers prefer applicants who are upbeat, confident and enthusiastic.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The holidays are over. It's time to get serious about finding that new job. So what's the first step?

item.title: Careers in Demand in Eastern New Mexico
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
From the Portales News Tribune: Health care is currently eastern New Mexico’s hottest industry for training and jobs, according to John Hemphill, manager or Workforce Connection facilities in eastern New Mexico. Renewable energy, wind and solar, is another thriving area for training and jobs Five of DWS’s top 10 positions in terms of job openings are in health care and related areas, including registered nurses, occupational therapists, physical therapists, speech-language pathologists, and medical scientists. Completing the top 10 list are retail sales persons, food preparation and service, first-line supervisors in retail, customer service representatives, and first-line supervisors in food preparation. Jai Oyler, an agent with Itsquest, a Clovis employment services agency, said there are gaps in many skilled labor areas. Young welders, for instance, are not coming along fast enough to replace those who are retiring, she said. Electric utilities, she said, are facing skilled worker shortages in many key areas. “They’re seeing shortages of hundreds of thousands of workers nationally over the next 10 years,” she said. She also said Itsquest has been getting requests for construction workers at Cannon Air Force Base and for a variety of positions at Sunland, the Portales-based processor of peanut products, as it readies to reopen after being shut down by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration due to salmonella contamination. In addition, she said, the Tres Amigas project near Clovis will need many construction workers when work begins this year. DWS also publishes a list of “careers in demand.” These are occupations that are expected to see the greatest number of new positions from 2010 to 2020, as a percentage of jobs in place in 2010. The top 10 on this list include:
  • Computer software engineers.
  • Personal and home care aides
  • Network systems and data communications analysts
  • Home health aides
  • Industrial engineers
  • Computer software engineers, systems software
  • Network and computer systems administrators
  • Computer security specialists
  • Computer systems analysts
  • Pharmacy Technicians

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Careers in Demand in Eastern New Mexico
Health care is currently eastern New Mexico’s hottest industry for training and jobs, according to John Hemphill, manager Workforce Connection in eastern New Mexico.

item.title: Spring is the Time to Get Serious About Your Job Search
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Now that the weather's warming, and the days are longer, it's time to shake off the winter doldrums, dust off that resume, and get serious about finding a better job. One of the things that holds people back is listening to their own internal critic. You know that voice, the one that says:
"There's nothing out there"
"Unemployment is so high in my city, what's the use?"
"You're too old to change careers"
"There's nothing in my field"
"I'm too busy to look for another job"
If any of that sounds familiar, it's time to have a talk with yourself. No matter where you live or what the employment situation is, employers are always looking for bright, talented people to fill jobs. Update your resume, develop a plan for what employers you're interested in approaching, and think about who in your life you can contact about your job search. The most fruitful method of job searching is through personal contacts (informational interviewing), and spring is the best time of year to get going!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Spring is the Time to Get Serious About Your Job Search
Now that the weather's warming, and the days are longer, it's time to shake off the winter doldrums, dust off that resume, and get serious about finding a better job.

item.title: Consistency is the Key to Job Search Success
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Many times my clients start out strong in their job search efforts, but slowly lose momentum as the challenges of everyday life intervene.
To be successful in a career transition or job search, it's important to have a plan with clearly delineated steps, clear goal and objectives, alternate methods of reaching your goals, and contingencies for when things go awry.
Any method of record-keeping will work, as long as you're faithful about keeping it up. Paper, computer, calendar, whatever your preference, just be sure you're keeping track of everything you've done and plan to do.
Set goals for how many people you'll contact this week.
How many research interviews will you do? How many phone calls will it take to schedule those interviews?
How much research time will it take to decide what companies you will approach this week? this month?
How many resumes will you need if you are looking in more than one field? Are you keeping track of which one you sent where?
Most important, don't let yourself get sidetracked by the demands of daily living. If you want a new job, you have to put in the effort, which takes time, diligence and creativity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Many times my clients start out strong in their job search efforts, but slowly lose momentum as the challenges of everyday life intervene.
Consistency is the Key to Job Search Success

item.title: Use Keywords to Get Your Resume Noticed
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: I am often asked about how to incorporate keywords into a resume. This is the same question as how to tailor your skills and experience to meet the needs of the employer. Many large companies use competency-based job descriptions and behavioral interviewing to choose candidates. If you create a resume based on research into the position, you will be prepared for whatever comes your way. Keywords are simply the skills and abilities that an employer wants in a top candidate. If you are a computer programmer, important keywords are the software you are proficient with. If you are an editor, keywords relate to the type of documents you work with and the software you use. If you are an administrative assistant, keywords relate to software, office processes such as calendaring, and the machines you can operate. Every position requires you to have knowledge, skills, and abilities. If you’re unsure how to describe these, there are many resources for you to use in your research. First, carefully read the entire job description. Next, read the company website for clues to what type of employee they value. Look on job boards for notices of similar jobs by the same company or the same industry. As you write accomplishment statements for your resume, take everything you have learned into account, and use the language of the employer. If they want applicants with mediation experience, talk about how you have resolved problems. If they want independent decision-makers, talk about examples of how you’ve led teams or work groups. If you need more help in writing about your skills and accomplishments, look at the website http://www.onetonline.org/ It lists thousands of job descriptions including the tasks, skills, abilities, work activities, training needed, and salaries by state and nationally. It even includes information on the interests, work styles, and work values of people who are successful in that job. There is plenty of information to get the juices flowing so you can incorporate key words that will take your resume to the top of the pile.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I am often asked about how to incorporate keywords into a resume. This is the same question as how to tailor your skills and experience to meet the needs of the employer
Use Keywords to Get Your Resume Noticed

White Mountain Drive.  For more information, go here.

item.title: Job-fair hopefuls see brighter prospects
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
A recent job fair in Albuquerque organized by New Mexico Workforce Connection was attended by 800 people and reported on krqe.com's website. Job seekers reported feeling optimistic about their chances after attending the job fair.
At this job fair, around 40 different companies showcased their businesses, each with positions available. Arthur Martinez, site manager for Workforce Connection in Albuquerque, said a wide variety of jobs were available from the professional to the service industry.
“I'm seeing lot more activity in employers, and they're interested in hiring,” said Martinez. "Typically, New Mexico, we're last entering the recession, and we're late exiting, but I anticipate there's some additional turnaround coming."
There is still a lot of competition on every position. Lockheed Martin is looking for call-center workers and said the interest is incredible.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A recent job fair in Albuquerque organized by New Mexico Workforce Connection was attended by 800 people and reported on krqe.com's website

SANTA FE, N.M. (AP) — Lawmakers are creating a task force to consider how
New Mexico can create more jobs in emerging and new industries. The
Legislative Council agreed Tuesday to establish a "jobs council" that will
include legislative leaders as ...

item.title: Sitel to Host Job Fair and Hire 350 Customer Care Positions
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Sitel, a leading global customer care provider,announced the addition of 200 
full-time positions and 150 temporary positions for its customer care call center 
in Albuquerque, New Mexico. In December, Sitel Albuquerque expanded the 1(st) floor of its
 45,000 square foot facility, adding an additional 320 seats. The growth is due to 
expanding volume with its clients, a Global Beverage Company and Global Satellite TV 
Provider. Newly hired Albuquerque associates will provide inbound customer care support. 
The temporary positions will provide a great opportunity to learn the business and those
hired in temporary positions may be eligible for future positions.

Sitel is working closely with the New Mexico Department of Workforce
Solutions and hosting onsite job fairs on Wednesday, May 15(th) from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. at the company's facility
at 4420 The 25 Way.
<http://online.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20130503-909279.html>

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sitel, a leading global customer care provider,announced the addition of 200 full-time and 150 temporary positions for its customer care call center in ABQ
Sitel to Host Job Fair and Hire 350 Customer Care Positions

item.title: New Mexico Gaining Jobs
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
From the Albuquerque Journal May 20 The Department of Workforce Solutions reports that New Mexico's unemployment rate dropped last month and that job growth has improved. State officials said Friday the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 6.7 percent in April. That's down from 6.9 percent in March and 7 percent in April 2012. New Mexico has gained about 7,900 jobs during the past 12 months, for a 1 percent growth rate. It's been five years since the state's employment growth was at or exceeded 1 percent, and the department said the state's economy "may be gathering momentum as we start a sustained recovery." State officials said nine industries have gained jobs and three have lost jobs since April 2012. The construction industry has picked up 1,800 jobs, which is its best performance since 2006.
Think your friends should see this? Share it with them!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Department of Workforce Solutions reports that New Mexico's unemployment rate dropped last month and that job growth has improved.

item.title: New Mexico Gaining Construction Jobs
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Albuquerque Business First reports that, New Mexico is slowly regaining its lost construction jobs. However, the number of construction jobs in New Mexico is still sitting at 16,000 below its peak level.
The state’s peak came during the boom of 2006, and in June of that year New Mexico had 59,600 construction jobs. In May of this year, the total was 43,600 — down 16,000, or 27 percent. New Mexico did gain 500 construction jobs last month and has been on a steady if modest gain for the year, adding 2,900 construction jobs since January as the housing market slowly continues its recovery in the Albuquerque area and other areas of the state.
The data comes from an analysis of U.S. Labor Department data by the Associated General Contractors of America.

item.title: Job Fairs in ABQ on Monday
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: Two major job fairs will be happening in Albuquerque starting on Monday. The first will be for the next Gordman's store set to open near the Coronado Center in Uptown Albuquerque. Company representatives expect to hire about 100 new employees for that location. The job fair will be held with the help of the New Mexico Workforce Connection. This will be from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. at the New Mexico Workforce Connection Office at 501 Mountain Road in Northeast Albuquerque. www.gordmans.com/Careers The second job fair is held by Sodexo UNM Sports and Leisure. This organization will be looking for 40 new servers who will handle the food and beverage services for the upcoming games for Lobo Football and Basketball season. Their job fair runs from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the McDavid Lounge on the southside of the Pit.

item.title: How To Choose a New Career
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: You lost your job. Got laid off. The company closed. Unemployment isn't enough. What do you do? Choosing a new direction can be difficult. If you liked your old job, you may try to find one exactly like it. If your research shows there are opportunities for people with your skills and experience, then your task is simpler. Not easy, but simpler. Polish up that resume. Network with everyone you know. Get your resume in front of decision makers. Settle in for a concentrated and targeted job search. If you didn't like what you were doing, or if the industry is declining, it may be time to look at something entirely different. But how do you choose?  Some people look at what's available. What jobs have the most openings, or pay the most. Sometimes that works, but often it backfires. Just because you know you can work as a nurse or a respiratory therapist doesn't mean you will enjoy the work, the environment or the people you will be working with. So, again, how do you choose? First you must know your skills, interests, and abilities and have a pretty good sense of the type of problems you want to solve. But if you've gone through a self-assessment and feel pretty confident about what you’ve got to offer, the next thing is motivation. Why do you want a job? Well, obviously, to make a living. But beyond that, people are motivated by different desires. Do you want security? A steady paycheck? Lifetime employment? Regular hours. Do you want the chance to achieve and be successful in an organization? These jobs require longer hours, are often more demanding, and are found in every industry. Do you want independence above all? You might be an entrepreneur, but be sure you're willing to work very, very hard to make a living. Do you want to offer service? Opportunities abound in the not for profit sector, from entry level clerical to directors of agencies, but be prepared for lower wages, long hours, and be sure you're willing to guard against burnout. Do you want to express your creativity? The arts may be for you. The good news is that opportunities exist in business, government, and not for profits.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How To Choose a New Career
You lost your job. Got laid off. The company closed. Unemployment isn't enough. What do you do?

item.title: Job Incentive Program Coming to New Mexico
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
The New Mexico Economic Development Department's Job Training Incentive Program (JTIP) Board approved $708,167 in funding at its June meeting to seven companies that will create 99 jobs around New Mexico with an average wage of $15.20.

Some of the companies involved inclue Neptune Aviation Services of Alamorgordo, Santa Fe Spirits of Santa Fe, PreCheck, Inc of Alamogordo, and CAaNES, LLC of Albuququerque.

To qualify, new or expanding companies must either create a product in New Mexico, or provide a non-retail service with 50 percent of the company's costumer or revenue base outside of the state. The eligible jobs must be full-time and year-round. The trainee must be a new hire to the company and have been a New Mexico resident for at least one year at any time prior to being hired. For more information on JTIP, visit www.goNM.biz.

item.title: Indian Motorcyles Coming to Albuquerque
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: The iconic U.S. brand Indian Motorcycles is back and coming to its first New Mexico dealership later this year. Business partners and cousins Michael Gaillour and Louis Herrera purchased a 9,000-square-foot building at 4509 Alameda Blvd NE, (on the corner of Alameda and Washington) where they will open Indian Motorcycle of Albuquerque this fall. In addition to motorcycle sales and service, the dealership will offer Indian Motorcycle parts, apparel, and accessories. Both the architect and the principal contractor are New Mexico firms. James B. Clark of Masterworks Architects designed the build-out and the principal contractor is Damian J. Chimenti of Insight Construction. Indian Motorcycle of Albuquerque is owned by cousins Louis Herrera and Michael Gaillour, native New Mexicans who grew up in Questa. Herrera graduated from New Mexico Highlands University in Las Vegas, New Mexico, and earned a Master’s degree from Purdue University. He also attended Darmouth College. He served in the U.S. Army and is currently a Lt. Colonel and battalion commander in the New Mexico National Guard. Gaillour graduated from the University of New Mexico with a degree in finance and has had a 30-year banking career. To learn more, please visit facebook.com/IndianMotorcycleABQ.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The iconic U.S. brand Indian Motorcycles is back and coming to its first New Mexico dealership later this year.

item.title: Oil Field Jobs in Hobbs, NM
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: Although the Albuquerque metro area’s jobs picture remains bleak, the oil patch in southeast New Mexico and in Hobbs is booming. Now economic development officials in the area are hoping to lure Albuquerque workers. On July 6, the Hobbs Chamber of Commerce placed an ad in the Sunday Albuquerque Journal for its Hobbs Jobs website in the hope of luring Albuquerqueans and other New Mexicans to move to the oil patch. The Hobbs Jobs site has more than 30 jobs listed, including positions for accountants, civil engineers, survey crew chiefs, electro maintenance techs, cooks and casino marketing managers. “We need builders here in Hobbs. If it is slow in Albuquerque, we would love to have Albuquerque builders build apartments in Hobbs, and our city has a really good incentive program to work with on that.”

item.title: Google to Bring Jobs to Moriarity
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded: The State Economic Development Department will be footing an estimated $1 million to help build sewer and water lines at the Moriarty Airport where Google is constructing a nearly 60,000-square-foot building. Google is looking to use the airport to develop solar-powered drones.The drones would fly at nearly 65,000 feet, providing communication services for rural areas. Before the Internet giant came to town, Titan Aerospace only had a few hangars and temporary offices. More than 200 aviation-related jobs are expected to come to Moriarity as a result of Google's presence,    Read more: http://www.koat.com/news/moriartys-partnership-with-google-may-bring-200-jobs/28202144#ixzz3FgptrHoD

item.title: To Find a New Job, Be Creative
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
What tools do you need to do a job search in a tight market?

Although much of the U.S. is pulling out of the unemployment slump, New Mexico is still experiencing high unemployment. There are signs that is changing.  We were the last to fall into recession, and we may be the last to cimb out, but while the situation is improving, it's still important to use every resource at your disposal.

The most important tool is your resume and cover letter

Both documents must be up to date, professionally written, focus on skills, achievements and the results that employers can expect you to provide.  If you are in doubt, get feedback on your document and be sure that you're not writing in jargon, old-fashioned language, or anything that sounds like a job description copied from the Internet.

Your Online Presence Counts

Many employers Google potential employees. They check Facebook, Linked In, Twitter and other social media sites.  If you are a professional in any field, or your job involves software or hardware, be sure that your online presence is up-to-date, professional, and persusive. If you don't know how to do that, get help from someone who does.

Your Elevator Speech is Critical

Named for the mythical ride up the elevator with the CEO of the company you're interested in, the elevator speech is a short summary of your skills, education, and qualifications for the job. In an interview, it may be phrased as: "Tell me about yourself", "Why are you interested in this job?",  "Why should I hire you?" or something related,  Be sure you can easily talk about the main points that qualify you for the position.

Yes, Research Matters

The more you know about a company, its history, strengths, weaknesses, mergers, hiring patterns, and brand, the more motivated an applicant you will appear to be. The time to research any company you land an interview with is more than worth the time you spend,

item.title: NM Community Colleges Get Funding for Job Training
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
Eleven community colleges in New Mexico will receive federal funding to provide innovative training programs, in partnership with local businesses, to help New Mexican adults advance into high-wage careers.

The funding, provided under Trade Adjustment Assistance Community College and Career Training (TAACCCT) competitive grant program, will allow these community colleges to expand and improve their ability to deliver education and career training programs that will help job seekers get the skills they need for in-demand jobs in New Mexicos health care industry.

 This funding will allow colleges across New Mexico to provide workers with quality job training to help fill New Mexicos expanding health care and technology workforce needs,

****

AerSale, an international supplier of aftermarket aircraft, will create 50 new jobs at the Roswell, New Mexico, International Air Center. The firm currently employs 100 workers in Roswell. The firm will begin hiring 30 certified aircraft technicians and 20 additional support personnel.

The Roswell International Air Center has a 13,000 foot runway that accommodates major aircraft manufacturers. Roswell's Air Center is also ideal for aircraft storage and maintenance, and can accommodate up to 800 aircraft.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: NM Community Colleges Get Funding for Job Training

item.title: High Paying Trucking Jobs Coming to Milan NM
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
A Delaware company announced Thursday it will invest $52 million in a truck-to-rail facility in Milan to help move oil from the Four Corners region to market.
NLG Energy Partners’ facility will create 62 jobs initially and another 50 or so within five years, according to the state Economic Development Department.
Most of the jobs will be New Mexico-based truck driving positions, and wages overall will average $92,000 a year plus benefits, said Angela Heisel, spokeswoman for the state Economic Development Department.
Cibola County will receive $1.2 million in Local Economic Development Act funds from the state to help with capital expenses on the project, Heisel said.
Oil trucked from the Four Corners area will be loaded into rail tankers at the facility, from which it can be shipped elsewhere.
Operations at the Milan truck offloading/rail loading facility are expected to begin in the third quarter of 2015.
“New Mexico is geographically positioned to become a leading logistics hub and we’d like to see this region replicate the success that’s taking place at our southern border with the location of Union Pacific there,” Gov. Susana Martinez said in announcing the facility.

item.title: Job Growth Up in New Mexico
item.dc:creator: cmarch555
item.content:encoded:
It's been a long time coming and we still have a long way to go, but 2014 saw positive job growth after years of shrinkage and stagnation, while neighboring states bounced back faster.
Statewide, more than 14,000 new jobs were created this year – 700 of them in construction, which had been absolutely crushed during the recession.
The biggest gains were in education, which grew even during the hard times, and health care. Between the two, the sectors gained more than 6000 new jobs in 2014.
The manufacturing sector is still losing jobs, however – losing 1500 statewide this year. 600 government jobs also went away this year, as most of the job growth in New Mexico has come in the private sector.
So, if you're looking, focus your job search efforts toward the more robust private sector. However, if you have specialized managerial or technical skills, even government may be a likely target. The most effective job search is multi-pronged, leaving nothing out.
